text: hello I'm Matt and welcome back to DIY
perks in this video I'm going to be
showing you how to build your very own
desk PC with a design that brings to the
table some very useful real-world
benefits
[Music]
[Music]
now building computers into window desks
has for a while now been a great way for
PC enthusiasts to express their interest
in hardware as a form of art but unlike
this the typical design is to have all
of the components built into a bulky
desktop which doesn't bring to the table
Parden phone many practical benefits
apart from showing off the hardware
however with this particular design
having all of the hardware in a rear
chamber it means that the desktop itself
can be thin and elegant and can be
folded away when the PC isn't in use
which is perfect for smaller spaces
where a large desk area like this would
otherwise be impractical despite this
minimalist elegance the component
chamber itself is absolutely vast
allowing for all sorts of powerful
hardware to be mounted inside now this
is where another element of the design
comes into play which is silence as this
chamber is completely airtight which
locks in any noise generated by the
components however as they are so
powerful they do generate a lot of heat
and that heat does need to be removed
so it utilizes water cooling to take the
heat away from the components and into
two large radiators in to side units and
these get them vented into the
surrounding air this works extremely
well and it's even tackles tricky issues
like pump noise and graphics card coil
whine and I'll be showing you the
thermals and sound emissions at the end
of this video and my goodness is
impressive especially considering the
amount of heat that it has to deal with
so it's elegant provides plenty of room
for high-end hardware that can be cooled
silently and it can be made extremely
compact in a room when folded away now
this video has a lot in it ranging from
custom water box and cable sleeving to
woodwork and DIY capacitive buttons so
grab yourself a drink or a snack and sit
back and enjoy
now before we get going I'd like to say
a huge thanks to these brands who have
sent various components over for the
build I'll be introducing these
individually as we go along and if
anything strikes your interest you can
find links to each of the products in
the description also there you can find
a 12 page guide to help you to construct
the main body of the case which includes
measurements for it and extra tips that
couldn't make it into the video due to
time constraints
it'll make building the case much easier
so have a look in the description for
more details so the material I suggest
using to build the case itself out of is
18 millimeter thick MDF as it's readily
available and very dense meaning it's
very good at blocking noise it is a very
dusty material when cut or standard
though so if like me you don't have a
workshop work outside and wear proper
breathing equipment as the dust is
definitely not something that you want
to be breathing in to make the central
component chamber you'll want to cut out
a large piece for the back followed by
two side pieces and two top pieces quite
importantly these side pieces need to
have some large cutouts made in them for
some connector panels to fit into later
which extend all of the connections to
provide access to all of the pores this
is because the central component chamber
will be completely sealed and would
otherwise block access to things like
the monitor outputs and USB ports etc so
having these extended to some panels
makes a lot of sense I also recommend
that the top piece has a cutout in it
too as this will allow space for buttons
or switches to be added which I'll go
into detail about later before fitting
these together however it's important to
work out a suitable component layout any
mounting holes need to be marked onto
the wood with a pencil and then
carefully drilled out but not all the
way through they just need to be deep
enough for some threaded inserts which
are screwin mounds that allow you to use
fine thread machine screws in
comparatively soft surfaces like MDF
these particular ones are for the
motherboard to sit on so at this point
some PCB pillars can be screwed into
them and the motherboard perched on top
to check accuracy I also made provision
for some extra long pillars just next to
the edge which will later be used for
securing the expansion cards this
process needs to be continued until you
have mounting holes for all of your main
components though like me you may need
to adjust these later or add some more
as the design evolved once you're happy
with the positioning of everything the
holes can be temporarily boned up with
blue TAC to stop any paint from clogging
them up when we reach that stage for now
though we need to mount our pieces
together and to do this we can clamp
them to the main sheet and flip the
whole thing over so that we can drill
some pilot holes through them both the
piece underneath can then be removed and
the holes on the main sheet can be
widened to turn them into through holes
which let the screws through without
resistance they also need to be
countersunk
so that the heads can sit below the
surface with that done the side piece
can now have some wood glue added along
its edge and then be pulled into place
with the screws after the remaining side
pieces have been added you should have a
very sturdy central compartment which is
comparatively vast for a pc case leaving
plenty of room for the internal
components so after filling and sanding
the countersunk screw holes it's ready
to paint and we're going to start with
some MDF primer as MDF is a very
absorbent material and sealing it is
very important for proper paint adhesion
with at least two coats of this applied
and dried we can now add some oil-based
undercoat being oil-based it very
quickly builds up relatively thick layer
this means that after giving it two
coats and leaving it as thoroughly dry
for a day or two it can be sanded down
if you try this when the paint hasn't
completely dried it will gum up the
sandpaper so it's much easier to wait a
while so this it comes off as fine dust
now as this is quite a large surface
area I used a small palm sander but you
can do it by hand if you like and if you
take your time you can sand it to an
almost plastic like appearance mimicking
a powder coat job this makes it a great
surface for the final top coat and I'm
going to use glossy spray paint for it
as it's quick to apply but as it's cold
and windy outside of the moment I'm
going to have to do it indoors
protecting the room and containing the
paint mist with some plastic dust covers
with that done and dry I also added a
few threaded inserts around the edge so
that a front panel could later be
screwed in place and to the side I
mounted a power strip which I could
later plug things into to keep the
wiring neat now part of the design is
that there are two side units that
stagger the central chamber these need
to be built separately to make them
removable so that the case can be
dismantled and be easier to transport if
ever needed their job is to primarily
house two large radiators that cool the
liquid in the water loop but they also
hide things like the power strip and
also all of the input and output ports
for cable routing purposes these units
can again be built out of MDF and
screwed and glued together remember
there are plans for these in the
description which should help you cut
them out properly including the position
and size of various holes like these
which will later be used to bolt the
unit to the main chamber the countersunk
screw holes on the front of this can
also be filled with wood filler and
sanded flat after which it can go
through the usual painting process of
first being under coated with MDF primer
and a couple of layers of oil-based
undercoat after which it can have a good
sanding down and then be painted with
the final colors I painted the inside
with black gloss avoiding spray paint
this time as it was a bit of a faff and
the outside I painted with a lovely
slightly blue shade of grey again in
gloss as this is my chosen outer color
looking good as you can see they've got
various openings and an internal brace
for adding support behind where some
right angle hinges can be mounted these
will later be used to allow the desk top
to be hinged up and down and can be
easily unlocked to allow them to be
folded away they're available on Amazon
so I've put a link to them in the
description these side units can now be
bolted to the main enclosure to ensure
an airtight seal around each bolt i
added some black tack just under the
heads which will make it completely
airtight once it's tightly bolted from
the other side now that they're secured
it should be looking something like this
the blue tack plugs can now be picked
out from the mounting holes and the
pillars screwed back in place with that
done it's finally time to start adding
the components the first one I'm going
to add is the power supply which is a
high efficiency unit that's been sent
over from C Sonic it's very powerful
capable of delivering up to 600 watts
and impressively it can do this silently
as it's entirely passive to mount it I
added some carbon fiber effect vinyl
wrap to a short aluminium right angle
and then used this to secure it in place
with that done it's time to start
working on the wort cooling loop that's
paramount in this whole design all of
the components I need for this have been
very kindly provided by alpha cool who
design and manufacture all sorts of
water cooling gear from radiators to
water blocks and reservoirs big shout
out to Dave who was very helpful in
getting the ball rolling on this
as the project relied so heavily on
these components as you might expect one
of the first components to consider is
the pump generally these allow for
different tops to be added for various
port configurations and I'm using a
solid brass one here capping off the
ports I don't need now as it's a pump it
obviously has moving parts so will
naturally generate vibrations as I'm
aiming for total silence for this build
it's important to physically isolate to
the pump so that these vibrations won't
transferred into the case getting
amplified in the process this is
surprisingly important imagine when a
phone is vibrating on the table there's
a big difference in sound level when
it's touching and it's the same
principle here so the first step in
isolating the pump is to 3d print a
little bracket for it and mount it to
the back we can now get for long pillar
supports and add some heat shrink over
them to give them a matte black
appearance after which they can be
screwed to the bracket some additional
tabs need to be added to these as well
which just adds some holes through which
we can thread some elastic to suspend it
from form or pillar supports which makes
for superb acoustic isolation now as you
can see I actually mounted this to a
backing platform which adds a really
cool lighting effect to make something
like this it's just a case of covering a
sheet of frosted acrylic with some vinyl
wrap and then carefully cutting your
desired light pattern out on the front
as you can imagine there are limitless
possibilities here to light up your
pattern some LED strips can be stuck
onto the back facedown and slightly
offset by a centimeter or so so that
they don't shine directly through the
pattern but rather get scattered
and light the pattern up in an even way
now as the vinyl isn't terribly thick
you may want to add a couple of layers
of it to prevent any light bleeding
through where you don't want it so that
gives you an example of how to do it and
it's simple yet effective whatever you
come up with for your design it can just
be screwed to the back of the case where
you want it and you can add as many of
these as you like just be creative and
have fun so with the pump now mounted
the next thing to add is an internal
radiator and the sole purpose of this is
to keep the air temperature inside the
case as low as possible this is because
the case is completely airtight so the
air temperature would just go up and up
from residue heat sources like the power
supply and hard drives having this
radiator inside with its own fans to
push the air through it means that the
internal air is kept close to the
temperature
the water in the loop I'll be doing some
thorough tests of this later so stick
around for that too again isolate any
vibration noise from the fans this time
it's important to suspend the whole
thing using elastic from the top of the
case using a sponge and some sticky back
velcro at the bottom to keep it vertical
again this should work really well but
we'll have to wait until later to know
for sure the next component to add is a
reservoir these are very useful to have
in a water loop as they make it much
easier to fill and they also help to
catch any air that might have gotten
trapped inside to hook this up I'm going
to use some EPDM rubber tubing which is
often used in vehicles where longevity
is paramount as it doesn't leach
anything into the water over time
visually it's not as nice as glass or
acrylic but it is my choice for this
build not only because of its longevity
but also because it provides a soft link
between the pump and the remaining
components aiding in noise reduction it
can simply be cut to length with
scissors and then pushed into what are
called compression fittings which
feature a barb for it to go over and a
cap that gets screwed down on top making
an extremely tight seal I mounted the
top end to one of the ports on the
radiator and the bottom end to the
intake port on the pump an additional
pipe was left loose to later be used as
a filling pipe the other port on the
radiator follows a short length to the
outside of the enclosure through a hole
this will later be hooked up to another
much larger radiator but more on that in
a bit as you can see the whole thing is
very wobbly but that's what I'm after as
it should be acoustically isolated
because of this so the next component to
add at this point is perhaps what you'd
call the heart of the PC which is of
course the motherboard this has been
sent over by asrock and is based around
intel's high-end x2 99 platform which
has been designed for high core count
cpus quad-channel memory and plenty of
PCI Express Lanes for a lot of
connectivity options now as x-two 99
processes demand a lot of power
the motherboard has an extensive power
delivery system which is cooled by these
heat sinks however to stop this heat
from being dissipated into the air
inside the case acting like a residue
heat source which the internal radiator
would have to deal with I'm going to
cool it directly with the water cooling
loop so that the heat can be transported
straight out of the case instead after
removing the heat sinks however I
realized that I'd need to make a custom
water block to make good thermal contact
with the heat producing components as
they are at varying Heights to do this I
first cut out two short strips of copper
and primed them by adding a thin layer
of solder to each I did likewise with a
larger strip which had various holes cut
out in it for mounting purposes I then
dabbed on some flux and clamped them
together in a vise carefully heating
them up with a blowtorch once they hit
the melting point of the solder they
welded strongly together becoming like a
single solid block once cooled down it
just needed to be cleaned up after which
one of alpha cools small general blocks
could be screwed in place on top when
the water passes through this block it
will pull any heat away keeping the
entire thing extremely cool which is
great news for the components I later
tested this with a thermal camera and as
you can see it does a great job
despite being custom-made with that done
the processor itself can be mounted I
have my supporters on patreon to thank
for this as it was with these funds that
it was purchased remember that you guys
get the entire project resources for
free so check out the special patreon
page to download them for those of you
who aren't patrons but want to support
the channel and get these free files as
well as those of past present and future
projects you can find a link to the
patreon page in the description so to
cool the processor it too needs a water
block adding this is one of the largest
ones that alpha cool makes and
should keep the temperatures in check
very nicely which is important as these
particular processes are known for
getting extremely hot due to how
powerful they are
so after bridging both water blocks with
a short interconnection tube the
motherboard itself is almost ready to
mount but before I do I'll add one more
component which is an ultra-fast m2 SSD
from Western Digital this has a huge 1
terabyte capacity and thanks to its
insanely high read and write speeds
should make the system feel extremely
snappy when in use to install it it's
just a case of screwing it to the
motherboard like so after which the
whole thing is ready to be mounted into
the case as we added the pillars for
this earlier it goes in without any
problems so now it's time to add the
graphics card and the one I'm going to
be installing is an RT X 2080 from ZOTAC
which they're very kindly sent over to
support the build with this is an
absolute beast of a card and is one of
the fastest currently available which is
great for heavy workloads like GPU
accelerated video rendering CAD or
modelling work and of course gaming it's
got a very capable cooling system
already but as I want to water call the
card and have to remove it to install
one of Alpha cools compatible blocks
just like with the motherboard
it's not just the processing unit that
means cooling but the power delivery
system as well this is where the water
block really comes into its own as it
can make direct contact with these
components to keep the temperature of
the entire card in check once it's
screwed in place this can now be
installed on the motherboard and linked
into the loop to support it and any
other expansion cards I might want to
add later I also screwed in place a
little bracket at the bottom for it to
attach to
so at this point the main components
have all been plumbed in and the flow
goes from the pump past a tea splitter
which will be used for drainage if ever
needed up into the graphics card down
into my custom motherboard waterblock
over into the CPU block and then up from
the motherboard and out into one of the
side units this will later be connected
to a radiator but before that gets added
we need to solve the unfortunate
situation of all the i/o connections
being marooned inside the case to make
them accessible externally I bought a
ton of short panel mount extension
cables these include DisplayPort
extensions USB extensions and even some
LAN ones mounted these to the MDF panel
I mentioned earlier and I sealed around
them with some sugru to make the MER
tight this could then be slotted into
place and plugged into the various port
now I also made an audio panel in a
similar way
featuring speaker and headphone sockets
some auxiliary inputs as well as XLR
microphone sockets this one just slotted
in to the opposite side behind the power
supply and I'm not too worried about the
messy appearance as it'll be hidden
later by the front panel with that done
it's time to mount the radiators that
are responsible for expelling all of the
heat that the PC generates and as you
can see they are absolutely colossal
which means that they'll be able to do
their job very effectively they can just
be mounted into each of the side units
like so and linked into the loop now
these radiators have drain ports on the
bottom which will come in useful if I
ever need to change the coolant so I
utilized them by attaching a short
length of tubing to them with some stop
valves on the ends which I can just keep
behind the unit until required before
moving on I also fitted a bank of fans
to the inside of each side unit these
fans barely spin at all and are
completely inaudible they just provide
gentle pressure to encourage the air to
circulate through the radiators and
we'll be seeing how well they keep the
system cool later on in the video
some removable panels finished off the
look nicely I also added a fill port to
the remaining reservoir tube and
suspended it with some elastic which
while not particularly pretty does do a
functional job of preserving the
acoustic isolation now it was just a
case of adding the few remaining
components like the hard drives which
were suspended from some more pillars
and some custom braided power cables and
now these take a lot of time to make and
root but they're definitely worth it for
the aesthetics to make them all I did
was cut through one wire at a time on
the original power cables and solder an
additional length to it as required as
the originals weren't quite long enough
I then covered the joins with heat
shrink threaded on the sleeving and
rejoined the wire at the other end doing
these one at a time ensures that there
are no crossed connections and I hope
you'll agree that once they're finished
they look really good they were all kept
neat and orderly with some 3d printed
cable combs and you can find the files
for these included with the project
resources so the last primary component
to add at this point is the memory and
Patriot have sent over a whopping 64
gigabytes of their VIPRE RGB line
specially for this build this is very
fast Ram and features internal RGB
lighting which can be configured to
light up any color you like with various
effects which really does finish off the
lighting element of this build and looks
absolutely awesome
now for most builds that would have been
all of the components done and dusted
but as I like good quality audio I'm
quite excited as Burson audio have sent
over for the build one of their powerful
audio amplifiers the Burson Audio Bang
in addition to their new and improved
headphone amplifier and DAC which is the
Burson audio playmate i used the
previous version of this in my last
build the wood and rope PC and have been
consistently impressed with the sound
quality
what makes these units unique in
addition to fantastic audio quality is
that they've been designed with op-amp
rolling in mind meaning that you can
change the sound characteristics by
simply swapping them out Burson have a
selection of these that can be purchased
separately allowing you to fine tune
them to your personal taste
once I fine tuned mine I mounted them to
the sheet of acrylic that had gone
through the special lighting effect
process earlier which in turn could be
mounted to the inside of the case it
might seem odd to have access to the
volume knob restricted like this by
locking it inside the case but the
playmate does support a remote control
so I can just adjust the volume that way
as needed to finish the build off it's
time for some woodwork to make a
hardwood top for it for this I got the
length of MDF and stuck some ash
hardwood strips around its perimeter to
give it the appearance of being solid
ash from the sides on top of this I then
glued down several ash planks and
clamped it all in place until it was set
as its surface ended up pretty rough I
took the blade out of a plane and
scraped it along the top to flatten
everything off and to neaten up all of
the edges and unify them I trimmed them
up with a plunge saw and then sanded the
whole thing down I then drilled a few
required holes in it and gave it two
coats of oil to protect it long-term and
too deep in the woods character making
it look absolutely stunning
now before attaching it I ran some black
tag around this gap so that it would
make a seal to keep in any noise once
the top is screwed in place
this gap allowed for access underneath
these three holes which have been made
for some brass caps to be fitted into as
these are actually going to be rigged up
as capacitive buttons for various
functions to achieve this we can use
these tiny little capacitive PCB
circuits which detect the presence of
skin and trigger a voltage output which
can be wired up to flip some relays to
achieve the desired switching now the
behavior of these boards can be adjusted
by bridging these little pads on the PCB
which changes it to function as a
latching switch instead of a momentary
one which is very useful functionality
you can find links to these super cheap
boards in the description as they're
always useful to have around for
implementing into projects I simply
glued them in place underneath the bust
disks and they detect whenever the brass
is touched which in turn flips some
relays I've wired up won't turn the PC
on followed by another to power up an
XLR microphone preamp and the last one
powers up the Burson amplifier
redirecting audio from the headphones to
the speaker's making them quick and easy
to switch between with that done the
loop can finally be filled
I used a premix for this as it has
additives inside to prevent bacterial
growth and to discourage corrosion now
it was quite tricky to get this filled
without any air pockets but once it was
done the pump could successfully move
the water around the loop which cools
all the components and looks absolutely
fantastic so with everything now sorted
on the inside it's time to seal it up
for this I made a frame out of MDF for a
glass panel to fit into the glass I'm
using is a double glazed unit which
should help to block out any noise and
is of course toughened I simply glued it
into my frame and sealed around it with
some more adhesive around the frames
edge I then struck down some draft
excluder which will make yet another
airtight seal once the frame is tightly
screwed in place on the front of the
case
now with the case being so shallow it's
not particularly stable but that's okay
as its intended to be tied into the wall
with some screws after which it becomes
extremely sturdy the last thing to do is
screw on the folding desk top which was
made in exactly the same way as the
smaller shelf completing the build

so with a complete it is conclusion time
was it all worth it now for me that
answer is an absolute yes despite the
amount of time that it took and it took
a long time I've really enjoyed using it
the past month and it's the best machine
I've ever used I've got a high refresh
rate monitor here on the wall a low
latency Mouse and it's just so slick and
responsive to use thanks to the high-end
hardware as well
now also does this silently during you
can't hear it there is a very low level
hum from the eight fans that are
spinning slowly but you can only hear
that if you duck down underneath the
desk and obviously that's not something
that you're generally going to do during
use but here is an example of that to
give you a general idea now one of the
reasons for the silent operation is of
course the glass as it locks in any
component noise here is it before and

the microphone is at the exact same
volume level between these recordings
very impressive results now a side
benefit of the component chamber being
completely sealed is that it will never
get dusty which from an aesthetic point
of view is really nice now another side
benefit which I may check out in the
future is that it would be possible to

evacuated meaning that condensation

of the biggest problems when using a

if you'd like to see that so in
conclusion I love it I think it was
worth it it's a super machine to use and
I think it's interesting as well just as
a concept and I hope that you have

full and I hope it's given you some
inspiration of something that you might
want to do yourself even if it's not

that there is a PDF file in the

tips that will help you along in making
it so before I go a final huge thanks
must go out to the various manufacturers
who have sent their products over to use
in this build
they've been very patient because it's

but I hope that they agree and I hope

but other than that I'm Matt you've been
